market_context: US stock futures are declining pre-market, with S&P 500 futures down 0.3-0.4% to around 6,902, Nasdaq 100 futures down 0.5% to 24,945, and Dow futures down 0.3% to 49,547, amid uncertainty from Trump's announcement of 15% global tariffs under Section 122 following the Supreme Court's rejection of prior tariffs.[3][4] Last week's equity gains (S&P 500 +1.1%, Nasdaq +1.5%) from tariff relief are overshadowed by trade policy risks and anticipation for Nvidia earnings on February 25.[1][3] Oil is falling on Iran tensions, while gold holds above $5,000 after a correction.[1][4]

predictions.reasoning: S&P 500 futures are down 0.3-0.4% to 6,902 amid Trump tariff turmoil after Supreme Court ruling, extending Sunday evening declines into open.[3][4] Last week's 1.1% gain faces headwinds from trade uncertainty and no major positive catalysts today before Nvidia earnings Wednesday.[1][3] Prediction markets imply S&P around 5,850-5,860 at 2pm EST, suggesting intraday downside pressure.[2]

Nasdaq 100 futures fell 0.5% to 24,945, hit harder by tariff risks on tech supply chains and China export concerns ahead of Nvidia earnings.[3][1] Tech 100 consolidating near 200-day MA at 24,600 with resistance at 50-day MA 25,300, limiting upside.[1] Broader market caution from unresolved Trump trade policy adds to pre-market weakness.[4]

Dow Jones futures down 0.3% to 49,547, tracking tariff uncertainty after Trump's 15% global levy announcement despite Supreme Court relief last week.[3][4] Retailer earnings this week highlight tariff costs, pressuring industrials.[4] Weaker weekly gain of 0.3% vs. S&P's 1.1% indicates vulnerability to trade news.[1]

Futures weakness in Nasdaq reflects pre-earnings caution for Nvidia reporting Q4 on Feb 25, with focus on AI demand amid competition and China risks.[1][3] No earnings today, so limited catalysts beyond broad market tariff sentiment.[3] Expectations high at $1.52 EPS on $65.56B revenue, but guidance key later in week.[3]
